chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect Morton's neuroma?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Typical symptoms of Morton's neuroma include:
    • Pain in the forefoot, most commonly felt in the third inter-metatarsophalangeal space, less commonly in the second, and rarely in the first or fourth.
    • Pain whilst walking, exacerbated by increased activity or particular footwear, and relieved by removal of footwear and massaging the toes. 
    • The sensation of having a 'pebble' or 'lump' under the metatarsal region when walking.
    • A sharp, stabbing, burning, or tingling sensation (sometimes described as feeling like an electric shock) in the distribution of the affected nerve.
  • Some people with Morton's neuroma may be asymptomatic, with the neuroma being detected as an incidental finding on examination of the foot for another reason.
  • On examination:
    • Pain is elicited on applying pressure to the involved inter-metatarsophalangeal space.
    • Try to elicit Mulder's click:
      • Try to grip the neuroma between your forefinger and thumb (with your thumb on the plantar aspect of the foot).
      • With your other hand, simultaneously squeeze the metatarsal heads (1–5) together in the transverse plane.
      • A click can be felt and heard as the enlarged nerve subluxes between the metatarsal heads as they are compressed.
      • Absence of this sign does not rule out neuroma.
    • Loss of sensation to the affected toes is a strong indicator of Morton's neuroma, but a sensory deficit may not be apparent on examination.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Location

  • The information on which inter-metatarsophalangeal space is most frequently involved is based on guidelines produced by the American College of Radiology [American College of Radiology, 2005] and the Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons [Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010].
  • The information on the characteristics of the pain are based on expert opinion in review articles [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Nazarko, 2011; Peters et al, 2011; Pomeroy et al, 2015; Richardson and Dean, 2014], and a case series of 115 people with features of Morton's neuroma looking at the efficacy of a staged treatment program (all of whom were asked to complete a questionnaire on their presenting complaints and symptoms) [Bennett et al, 1995].
  • The information on the sensation of having a pebble or lump under the metatarsal region is based on expert opinion from review articles [Summers, 2010; Adams et al, 2011; Nazarko, 2011; Peters et al, 2011; Pomeroy et al, 2015] and a case series comparing two conservative treatment methods [Saygi et al, 2005].
  • The information that loss of sensation to the affected toes is a strong indicator of Morton's neuroma is based on expert opinion from review articles [Nunan and Giesy, 1997; Nazarko, 2011], a Cochrane systematic review of the evidence on interventions for the treatment of Morton's neuroma [Thomson, 2004], and the expert opinion of a previous reviewer of this CKS topic. The fact that a sensory deficit may not be apparent on examination is based on expert opinion in a clinical practice guideline [Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014] and a clinical consensus statement [Thomas et al, 2009a].
  • The information that some people with Morton's neuroma may be asymptomatic is based on expert opinion in a review article [Summers, 2010].

Mulder's click

  • The recommendation to try and elicit Mulder's click is based on expert opinion from a clinical practice guideline [Association of Extremity Nerve Surgeons, 2014] and review articles [Adams, 2010; Summers, 2010; Peters et al, 2011; Pomeroy et al, 2015].
